cancel.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to decide that something that was officially planned will not happen
cancel.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: I’m afraid I’ll have to cancel our meeting tomorrow.
You’ll just have to ring John and cancel.
cancel.translation[0].definitions[0].not: In everyday English, people often say call something off rather than cancel something:
cancel.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to end an agreement or arrangement that you have with someone
cancel.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: I phoned the hotel to cancel my reservation.
The bank agreed to cancel all the company’s debts.
cancel.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to say officially that a document can no longer be used or no longer has any legal effect
cancel.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: I phoned the bank to cancel the cheque.
cancel.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: cancel
to decide that something that was officially planned will not happen
The teacher was ill so classes were cancelled for the day.
I was feeling better so I cancelled my doctor’s appointment.
They were forced to cancel the concert when the conductor became ill.
call off
to cancel a meeting, game, or event that you have organized. Call off is less formal than cancel and is very commonly used in everyday English
Linda decided to call the wedding off.
The game was called off due to heavy rain.
be off
if an event or activity is off, it has been cancelled because of a sudden problem or change in someone’s plans
I’m afraid the party’s off. Nick won’t let us use his apartment.
Myers called me yesterday to tell me that the deal was off.
postpone
to decide to do something at a later time, instead of the time that was officially planned
The show has been postponed until next Saturday.
shelve
to decide not to continue with a plan, project etc although it may be considered again at some time in the future
Plans for a new stadium have been shelved for now.
The project had to be put on ice due to lack of funding.
Blears called for the discussions to be put on ice until after the elections.
annul
to officially decide that a marriage, result, or agreement has no legal authority and is therefore cancelled
The election results were annulled by the courts.
A marriage can be annulled if there has been lack of consent.
cancel.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to arrange that a planned activity or event will not now happen
cancel.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Airport security has been increased but there is no intention of cancelling flights.
Because of the takeover moves the meeting was cancelled.
Some airlines have been forced to cancel orders.
cancel.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to end an agreement or arrangement that exists in law
cancel.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: You can suspend or even cancel your contract for the period you are away.
cancel.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to draw lines across a document so that it no longer has any legal effect
